title: How to Roleplay in Video Games

steps.headline: Don't take out your map/compass in a storm/at night.
steps.description: Unless you have an umbrella, you're likely to get your map wet. Likewise, unless you're near a light (or cast a light spell or have night vision), you would not be able to see clearly.

steps.headline: Don't run everywhere.
steps.description: Unfortunately, people don't have infinite breath. When you aren't running from ogres or dashing to save your mother/father/sibling/pet from their inevitable, scripted demise, walk or jog instead.

steps.headline: On a related note, don't run with bare feet on hard surfaces.
steps.description: Unless you are playing as a race that can't wear shoes (such as the Argonians and Khajiit in the TES series), it's highly doubtful that one would wear no shoes on concrete, pavement, rock, etc. That would be like sending a midget demon to stab your feet repeatedly.

steps.headline: Try to wear gloves or gauntlets.
steps.description: If you're going to be picking up meat from animal corpses or stealing from peoples' bodies, you probably want to wear hand protection. If you're just not the sort to wear them, frequently go to sinks (or rivers, whichever you prefer) and act as if your character has some sense of cleanliness.

steps.headline: Find somewhere to sleep in a storm.
steps.description: The roads would be muddy and difficult to walk in when it rains. At the very least, try to find a tree or cave overhang.

steps.headline: Give your character a suitable name for their race in their setting.
steps.description: An elf probably won't be named Bob. A demonic overlord isn't likely to, either. For an average human, however, it would be fine.

steps.headline: Give him/her a backstory.
steps.description: If there's one attached by default (like in most RPGs), elaborate on it. For example: Say you're playing as a Siren in 'Borderlands 2'. You want to kill Handsome Jack because he's out to murder you, that's a given. But what if he was your boyfriend that was caught cheating on you with another member of the Crimson Raiders, and now you hate both Jack and that member, and the only reason you put up with that member is because of the Raiders?

steps.headline: Give them a personality.
steps.description: "Good, kind-hearted, would do anything for any stranger s/he ever met" isn't a personality, it's a cliché that should be avoided like the plague. Everyone has something dark or weird about them. It's your job to find out what your character's something is.

text: Making Your Game More Realistic Don't take out your map/compass in a storm/at night. Unless you have an umbrella, you're likely to get your map wet. Likewise, unless you're near a light (or cast a light spell or have night vision), you would not be able to see clearly. Don't run everywhere. Unfortunately, people don't have infinite breath. When you aren't running from ogres or dashing to save your mother/father/sibling/pet from their inevitable, scripted demise, walk or jog instead. On a related note, don't run with bare feet on hard surfaces. Unless you are playing as a race that can't wear shoes (such as the Argonians and Khajiit in the TES series), it's highly doubtful that one would wear no shoes on concrete, pavement, rock, etc. That would be like sending a midget demon to stab your feet repeatedly. Try to wear gloves or gauntlets. If you're going to be picking up meat from animal corpses or stealing from peoples' bodies, you probably want to wear hand protection. If you're just not the sort to wear them, frequently go to sinks (or rivers, whichever you prefer) and act as if your character has some sense of cleanliness. Find somewhere to sleep in a storm. The roads would be muddy and difficult to walk in when it rains. At the very least, try to find a tree or cave overhang. Creating Your Character Give your character a suitable name for their race in their setting. An elf probably won't be named Bob. A demonic overlord isn't likely to, either. For an average human, however, it would be fine. Give him/her a backstory. If there's one attached by default (like in most RPGs), elaborate on it. For example: Say you're playing as a Siren in 'Borderlands 2'. You want to kill Handsome Jack because he's out to murder you, that's a given. But what if he was your boyfriend that was caught cheating on you with another member of the Crimson Raiders, and now you hate both Jack and that member, and the only reason you put up with that member is because of the Raiders? Give them a personality. "Good, kind-hearted, would do anything for any stranger s/he ever met" isn't a personality, it's a cliché that should be avoided like the plague. Everyone has something dark or weird about them. It's your job to find out what your character's something is.
